intro: Lipocarpha abietina, commonly known as the bog sedge, is a herbaceous plant native to wetland and marsh environments in temperate regions. It is characterized by its tall, slender stems and narrow, grass-like leaves that are typically arranged in a dense, cylindrical cluster. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are clustered in spikelets, typical of the Cyperaceae family. It thrives in poorly drained soils and plays a role in stabilizing wetland ecosystems. Lipocarpha abietina is often found in association with other moisture-loving plants in swampy or boggy habitats.
